paraId="203" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Summary of Damages Prevented by Potential LTFS Projects</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="204" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The following figure summarizes the estimated damages prevented by the potential LTFS local protection projects, combined with a 20% flow reduction on the Red River main stem. Prevented damages are estimated for 100 year, 200 year and 500 year floods.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="205" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Prevented damages are computed for both (1) baseline hydrology, or that currently used by the USACE and (2) wet period hydrology, or that recommended by the current USACE feasibility study for Fargo-Moorhead flood protection.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="206" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Depending on the hydrology used, damages prevented by the potential LTFS projects will range from about $3 to [$]4 billion for a single 100 year flood, from $6.5 to [$]8 billion for a single 200 year flood, and from $10 to [$]13 billion for a single 500 year flood.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="207" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Working together with sound, proactive floodplain management, the potential LTFS projects can make a profound, measureable difference far into the future for the Red River basin. ------------------------------------------------------------------------ Total Prevented Damages of Potential LTFS Projects--Red River Basin Part IV: Moving Ahead With Integrated Action 10 Conclusions and Recommendations for Action</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="208" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The basin of the Red River of the North, historically subject to widespread chronic flooding, regularly sustains millions of dollars in economic damages for each flood event. The Red River Basin Commission (RRBC) identified the following conclusions on structural and nonstructural strategies needed for permanent flood solutions in the basin and recommendations for action for states (individually and collectively) and the Federal Government to consider as they fund and implement Long Term Flood Solutions (LTFS) for the Red River Basin in Minnesota and North Dakota. These recommendations are built around the basin-wide LTFS ``Level of Protection Goals'' adopted by the RRBC in 2010 together with related flood risk reduction needs. The recommendations aim to move basin leaders from the usual response of reacting to the most recent major flood experience to a proactive, long-term plan with appropriate protection levels basin wide. If implemented, these recommendations will significantly reduce the risk of flood damages, and minimize disruption and economic loss and thus facilitate and expedite recovery after spring and summer floods.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="209" speaker="Mr. Finney ">These recommendations cannot be successful without the dedicated local, state and Federal participation in funding and commitment to implement. 1. Immediate Needs/Critical Risks: Fargo-Moorhead, Devils Lake <bullet> Under current conditions, the Fargo-Moorhead metropolitan</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="210" speaker="Mr. Finney ">area could get, in a major 500 year level flood, $9 to $10</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="211" speaker="Mr. Finney ">billion or more in basin damages, according to the USACE. <bullet> Current levels of protection for Fargo-Moorhead are</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="212" speaker="Mr. Finney ">inadequate. Protection should be increased to enable a</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="213" speaker="Mr. Finney ">successful 500 year flood fight. <bullet> Protection measures for Fargo-Moorhead should be</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="214" speaker="Mr. Finney ">economically viable and provide the least level of adverse</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="215" speaker="Mr. Finney ">impacts to others. <bullet> A diversion of the Red River around Fargo-Moorhead would</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="216" speaker="Mr. Finney ">provide the protection needed to endure a successful 500 year</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="217" speaker="Mr. Finney ">flood fight if it were supplemented by retention and other</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="218" speaker="Mr. Finney ">available options to achieve the RRBC's proposed LTFS level of</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="219" speaker="Mr. Finney ">protection goals. <bullet> Retention to achieve the potential 20 percent flow reduction</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="220" speaker="Mr. Finney ">on the main stem should be aggressively pursued upstream of</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="221" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Fargo-Moorhead to decrease the duration, scope, and level of</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="222" speaker="Mr. Finney ">floods in the Fargo-Moorhead area, downstream communities, and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="223" speaker="Mr. Finney ">rural areas.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="224" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 1.1</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="225" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The flood protection trajectory that has increased protection in the Fargo-Moorhead metro area since the 2009 flood should continue. State and Federal funds, with local government cost share, should continue supporting ongoing dike construction, property acquisitions, flowage easements, and flood infrastructure projects to be able to fight at least a 100 year flood, and upwards of a 500 year flood in the long-term.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="226" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 1.2</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="227" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Progress towards the proposed $1.77 billion diversion should be continued utilizing local, state, and Federal funds so that, combined with current flood protection strategies, this community will have the capacity within 10 years to wage a successful flood fight equal to or greater than the LTFS 500 year flood.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="228" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 1.3</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="229" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Retention upstream of the Hickson and Abercrombie stream gage for a flow reduction of 20 percent (minimum) should be advanced with shared funding by the F-M flood Diversion Authority working with local and joint water boards, using city, local, state, and Federal funds.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="230" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 1.4</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="231" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Leaders in state government in North Dakota and Minnesota, along with key local government officials and with input from the Diversion Authority and Federal agencies, should convene by early 2012 to determine the non-Federal cost share formula for the Locally Preferred Plan ($1.77 billion) diversion, and related $3.5 million operational estimates. <bullet> Rising levels of water in the Devils Lake region have</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="232" speaker="Mr. Finney ">increased the potential for a natural overflow that could</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="233" speaker="Mr. Finney ">discharge approximately 14,000 cubic feet per second (cfs) of</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="234" speaker="Mr. Finney ">water into the Sheyenne River, triggering prolonged flooding</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="235" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and catastrophic downstream water quantity and quality problems</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="236" speaker="Mr. Finney ">in the Sheyenne and Red Rivers. This crisis should continue to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="237" speaker="Mr. Finney ">be addressed with immediate local, state and Federal action.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="238" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 1.5</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="239" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The recommendations developed by the Devils Lake Executive Committee through the work of the Devils Lake Collaborative Working Group should continue to be supported by the state of North Dakota, local authorities, and Federal and Tribal governments to guard against critical risks.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="240" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 1.6</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="241" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The RRBC and IRRB should distribute information with downstream interests and jurisdictions providing progress and timelines on Devils Lake activities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="242" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 1.7</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="243" speaker="Mr. Finney ">A comprehensive model using real-time data to determine the effects of releases of Devils Lake water via the various outlet channels on the Sheyenne and Red Rivers should be examined by local leaders and state and Federal agencies to determine needs and related costs. The examination should include the integration of various models already in use by the USGS, the NWS, the NDSWC, and the USACE and be facilitated by the RRBC. 2. Cornerstone Solutions: Floodplain Management</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="244" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2A Floodplain Management--Nonstructural Strategies <bullet> A majority of the basin population lives adjacent to the Red</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="245" speaker="Mr. Finney ">River main stem and its tributaries at the lowest geographic</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="246" speaker="Mr. Finney ">elevation subject to flooding with no comprehensive, basin-wide</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="247" speaker="Mr. Finney ">approach to floodplain management, nor is there a mechanism to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="248" speaker="Mr. Finney ">align the variations in local, state, and Federal rules,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="249" speaker="Mr. Finney ">regulations, and approaches. <bullet> Nonstructural floodplain management strategies should be an</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="250" speaker="Mr. Finney ">integral component of reducing flood damage risks in the basin. <bullet> The most effective overall technique for living with floods</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="251" speaker="Mr. Finney ">is for basin citizens to take personal responsibility for their</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="252" speaker="Mr. Finney ">own flood risk and for the sustainability of our natural</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="253" speaker="Mr. Finney ">resources. <bullet> Minnesota and North Dakota should fund and administer flood</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="254" speaker="Mr. Finney ">mitigation policy consistently throughout the Red River basin</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="255" speaker="Mr. Finney ">so that a flood event in excess of the 100 year becomes the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="256" speaker="Mr. Finney ">benchmark for managing the risk of flooding, regulating</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="257" speaker="Mr. Finney ">development in the floodplain, and for developing flood risk</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="258" speaker="Mr. Finney ">reduction projects around existing and newly developed areas.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="259" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2A.1</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="260" speaker="Mr. Finney ">State floodplain regulations and local zoning ordinances should contain criteria for new residential, commercial, industrial, and agribusiness development that requires the largest of the following protection standards: <bullet> 100 year flood plus 3. <bullet> 200 year flood plus 1. <bullet> flood of record plus 1.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="261" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2A.2</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="262" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Buildings located in at-risk areas where structural measures cannot accomplish the recommended flood protection levels or are not economically feasible should be publicly acquired and removed over the next 3 to 5 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="263" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2A.3</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="264" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Local governments in the basin should update floodplain ordinances in the next 3 years, not permit new development in areas of high risk of flooding immediately adjacent to the Red River and tributaries, and minimize the use of variances, unless protected by elevation or another acceptable FEMA strategy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="265" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2A.4</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="266" speaker="Mr. Finney ">A review of basic floodplain regulations and programs should be undertaken by appropriate agencies and stakeholders of local, state and Federal standards, to include:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="267" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2A.4.1 An evaluation of the appropriate standards and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="268" speaker="Mr. Finney ">regulations for development throughout the basin, including the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="269" speaker="Mr. Finney ">adequacy of the 100 year regulatory minimum standard (to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="270" speaker="Mr. Finney ">include FIRMS) and the consideration of future standards to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="271" speaker="Mr. Finney ">reduce losses;</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="272" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2A.4.2 An analysis of community and state compliance with</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="273" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the flood insurance program, to include an analysis of proposed</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="274" speaker="Mr. Finney ">mandatory flood insurance for structures protected by dikes,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="275" speaker="Mr. Finney ">identification of impediments to, and potential tools and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="276" speaker="Mr. Finney ">resources for, participation in FEMA's community Rating System,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="277" speaker="Mr. Finney ">determination of the feasibility of insurance development, and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="278" speaker="Mr. Finney ">a strategy to prompt a basin-wide reduction in flood insurance</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="279" speaker="Mr. Finney ">rates;</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="280" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2A.4.3 An analysis of the use of variances by local</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="281" speaker="Mr. Finney ">governments; the reasons for and consequences of using</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="282" speaker="Mr. Finney ">variances for individuals, communities, and state; and most</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="283" speaker="Mr. Finney ">effective way(s) to track and document the use of variances.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="284" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2A.5</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="285" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Every community and county in the basin should work toward joining or improving their rating through the national FEMA Community Rating System to achieve lower flood insurance premiums for their residents (40-45 percent discounts) by 2015 as part of their mitigation plan update.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="286" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2A.6</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="287" speaker="Mr. Finney ">A Floodplain Bill of Rights, to include a floodplain map and flooding history, should be developed by RRBC with local government, realtors, builders, developers, FEMA, and state agency participation (2012).</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="288" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2A.7</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="289" speaker="Mr. Finney ">RRBC should develop education materials on the floodplain related to the floodplain, insurance, personal decisions, and the Floodplain Bill of Rights, to be distributed to the public, realtors, lenders, and others (2012).</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="290" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2A.8</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="291" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The USACE nonstructural assessment of identified structures has been completed for the F-M diversion project along the main stem in six counties deemed economically feasible for nonstructural mitigation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="292" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2A.8.1 The USACE should expand its assessment along the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="293" speaker="Mr. Finney ">entire main stem.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="294" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2A.8.2 A local sponsor should be identified to provide the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="295" speaker="Mr. Finney ">non-Federal cost share of 35 percent and implement the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="296" speaker="Mr. Finney ">mitigation in the next 3 to 5 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="297" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2A.8.3 Congress should authorize such a project and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="298" speaker="Mr. Finney ">appropriate approximately $12 million in funding for the 65</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="299" speaker="Mr. Finney ">percent Federal cost share to mitigate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="300" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2A.9</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="301" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Minnesota and North Dakota should use their respective state Silver Jackets (Flood and Hazard Mitigation) teams to regularly communicate issues regarding flood mitigation efforts in the Red River Basin. Silver Jackets team members from Minnesota and North Dakota should contribute to a collaborative interstate strategy for flood recovery and projects for mitigation efforts for the Red River of the North basin, to be coordinated with the RRBC and others as deemed appropriate.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="302" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2B Floodplain Management--Raising Levels of Protection <bullet> Comprehensive and strategic level of protection goals are</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="303" speaker="Mr. Finney ">needed for the entire basin. To this point, existing levels of</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="304" speaker="Mr. Finney ">protection have been based most often on the most recent flood</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="305" speaker="Mr. Finney ">experience, political will, and funding availability. <ctr-circle> The Minnesota and North Dakota legislatures should use</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="306" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the RRBC Level of Flood Protection Goals as a guide to future</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="307" speaker="Mr. Finney ">basin flood risk reduction strategies. (See ``Level of Flood</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="308" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Protection Goals'' adopted by the RRBC Board (2010) in LTFS</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="309" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Report, Ch. 8. Analysis assumes required freeboard.[)]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="310" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Major Urban/Metropolitan Areas <ctr-circle> Fargo-Moorhead (see Section 1. Biggest Risks). <bullet> Grand Forks-East Grand Forks. Over the next 20 to 25 years,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="311" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Minnesota and North Dakota should support increasing protection</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="312" speaker="Mr. Finney ">to a 500 year flood level for Grand Forks-East Grand Forks by</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="313" speaker="Mr. Finney ">improving the cities' current 200 to 250 year protection with</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="314" speaker="Mr. Finney ">upstream retention that achieves the potential minimum 20</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="315" speaker="Mr. Finney ">percent flow reduction on the Red River main stem at Grand</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="316" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Forks. <bullet> Winnipeg has elevated its level of protection to 700 years</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="317" speaker="Mr. Finney ">by recent expansion of their diversion following the 1997</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="318" speaker="Mr. Finney ">flood. Since its construction and subsequent first use in 1969,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="319" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the floodway has operated over 20 times and prevented more than</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="320" speaker="Mr. Finney ">$10 billion in flood damages. This model shows the importance</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="321" speaker="Mr. Finney ">of long range planning to realize the protection required from</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="322" speaker="Mr. Finney ">potential large floods.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="323" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.1</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="324" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Grand Forks and East Grand Forks should each request the 500 year or greater level of protection through the appropriate state and Federal legislative avenues. Planning should recognize the degree to which the strategy of retention can assist in achieving this level of protection for the two cities.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="325" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.2</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="326" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The RRBC shall facilitate an exchange between officials in Winnipeg, Manitoba, and Fargo-Moorhead local government officials, the F-M Diversion Authority, and the public for the purpose of sharing Winnipeg's experiences and expertise on the development and expansion of that city's diversion, including engineering, construction, and operation and maintenance of the Red River Floodway.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="327" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Critical Infrastructure: <bullet> Critical infrastructure needs to be protected from flooding</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="328" speaker="Mr. Finney ">to the greatest levels practical. If adversely affected by</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="329" speaker="Mr. Finney ">flooding, infrastructure such as water and waste water</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="330" speaker="Mr. Finney ">facilities, airports, hospitals, transportation, regional</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="331" speaker="Mr. Finney ">communications facilities, or chemical storage sites can</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="332" speaker="Mr. Finney ">experience major disruptions, resulting in harm to the people,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="333" speaker="Mr. Finney ">economy, and environment of the basin.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="334" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.3</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="335" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Over the next 3 to 5 years, state emergency management officers shall facilitate the identification and documentation of at-risk critical basin infrastructure and report to the state legislatures in the annual LTFS update.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="336" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Small Cities and Municipalities: <bullet> By 2015, cities in Minnesota and North Dakota on the main</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="337" speaker="Mr. Finney ">stem, tributaries, and in other flood prone areas should</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="338" speaker="Mr. Finney ">achieve protection to the 100 year level or 3 of freeboard the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="339" speaker="Mr. Finney ">largest flood in their area plus 3 of freeboard, whichever is</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="340" speaker="Mr. Finney ">greater. <bullet> Once cities have achieved this level of protection,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="341" speaker="Mr. Finney ">additional protection should be pursued towards achieving</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="342" speaker="Mr. Finney ">greater than 200 year flood protection using upstream</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="343" speaker="Mr. Finney ">retention. Flood flow reduction from upstream retention can</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="344" speaker="Mr. Finney ">further complement the current levees and other strategies</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="345" speaker="Mr. Finney ">underway or contemplated.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="346" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.4</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="347" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Community structural projects in collaboration with the RRWMB and RRJWRD should be funded in the next state funding cycle for each respective state. See attached funding timeline table D-31 and Level of Protection Appendix D, D-3.1, p. 12 with state, local and Federal funding.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="348" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Rural Residences and Farmsteads:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="349" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Funding ring dikes or elevating of buildings for rural residents and farmsteads in flood prone areas should protect to 3 above the 100 year level or 3 above the largest flood in their area, whichever is greater.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="350" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.5</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="351" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Structural projects identified in collaboration with the RRWMB and RRJWRD for rural areas, including ring dikes and rural property acquisitions, should be funded beginning in the next state funding cycle through 2015 for each respective state. For those projects that become necessary only after future floods, funding shall become available in subsequent funding cycles. See attached funding table D-31 and Level of Protection Appendix D, D-3.1, p. 12.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="352" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Agricultural Cropland: <bullet> Agriculture is an economic mainstay of the basin, with basin</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="353" speaker="Mr. Finney ">farms experiencing composite net returns of $3 billion or more</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="354" speaker="Mr. Finney ">annually. <bullet> Adequate drainage, whether surface or tile, is crucial to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="355" speaker="Mr. Finney ">crop production in the basin. <bullet> Studies such as the timing analysis study suggest that</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="356" speaker="Mr. Finney ">improvements to drainage systems in areas that contribute</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="357" speaker="Mr. Finney ">consistently to the rising side of the Red River flood</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="358" speaker="Mr. Finney ">hydrograph (early water) have the potential to help reduce Red</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="359" speaker="Mr. Finney ">River flood peaks if they can move runoff through the system</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="360" speaker="Mr. Finney ">ahead of flood peaks. (Minnesota Flood Damage Reduction</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="361" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Workgroup Technical Paper No. 11) <bullet> At this time, no comprehensive, systematic approach exists</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="362" speaker="Mr. Finney ">to coordinate the release of water in the current drainage</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="363" speaker="Mr. Finney ">system based upon this timing analysis. Recent improvements in</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="364" speaker="Mr. Finney ">modeling, flow data, and elevation data can be utilized to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="365" speaker="Mr. Finney ">better manage water to reduce flooding on the Red River. <bullet> The strategies that slow water or hold it on the land</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="366" speaker="Mr. Finney ">slightly longer (while allowing for timely movement in the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="367" speaker="Mr. Finney ">drainage system) are best implemented through land use and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="368" speaker="Mr. Finney ">easement programs that take into account landowner impacts, as</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="369" speaker="Mr. Finney ">well as benefits to the local area the main stem. <bullet> Potential exists to appropriate new Federal funding for land</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="370" speaker="Mr. Finney ">management to the basin through the next U.S. farm bill that</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="371" speaker="Mr. Finney ">will assist landowners in reducing runoff, reducing erosion,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="372" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and improving water quality. This effort will come through</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="373" speaker="Mr. Finney ">programs administered by the Natural Resource Conservation</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="374" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Service or its designee.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="375" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.6</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="376" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The RRRA, RRWMB, and RRJWRD, with appropriate state agencies, local government, and commodity group participation and support, should develop a multipurpose drainage strategy for agricultural land that evaluates the following:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="377" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2.10.1 Designed and engineered for both private benefits and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="378" speaker="Mr. Finney ">public water management objectives.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="379" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2.10.2 Temporary detention (slowing down of water) by land</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="380" speaker="Mr. Finney ">management practices and land use changes.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="381" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2.10.3 Side inlet controls for all ditches.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="382" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2.10.4 Use of drainage for peak flow reductions and erosion</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="383" speaker="Mr. Finney ">control.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="384" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2.10.5 Rate and volume of water related to field and drain</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="385" speaker="Mr. Finney ">capacity.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="386" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2.10.6 Timing and movement of water in an equitable manner.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="387" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2.10.7 Landowner incentives and needs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="388" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2.10.8 Adding drainage components to hydrologic models.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="389" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2.10.9 Need for studies, strategies, moratoriums, and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="390" speaker="Mr. Finney ">additional information.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="391" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.7</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="392" speaker="Mr. Finney ">River channel maintenance such as snagging and clearing of trees, including the removal of trees that have or are at risk of falling into rivers and waterways, should be continued as necessary to maintain open waterways systems. The two states should continue to fund this effort: under current policies, North Dakota at its level of about $1 to $2 million, and Minnesota to restore its historic level of $150,000 per year.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="393" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.8</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="394" speaker="Mr. Finney ">For purposes of achieving long-term flood retention and other benefits, Minnesota should provide state funding through bonding of $10 million a biennium for the Red River basin through the Board of Water and Soil Resources for Reinvest In Minnesota (RIM) easements to match or supplement Federal USDA conservation funding such as the Wetland Reserve Program, Conservation Reserve Program, EWP, and Environmental Quality Assurance Programs to achieve long term flood retention to leverage Federal funding in the next 5 year farm bill and for other benefits.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="395" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.9</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="396" speaker="Mr. Finney ">A basin wetland bank whereby farmers/landowners can purchase and exchange wetland credits should be developed by Minnesota, North Dakota, and South Dakota in partnership with NRCS and the local joint water resource districts in North Dakota and joint watershed districts in Minnesota.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="397" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.10</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="398" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The following pilot projects, demonstrations, and studies should be authorized and funded:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="399" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2B.10.1 Drainage as a Flood Reduction Tool Analysis: The</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="400" speaker="Mr. Finney ">RRRA, with appropriate state agency support, shall initiate an</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="401" speaker="Mr. Finney ">analysis of how to better utilize the surface drainage system</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="402" speaker="Mr. Finney ">to lower spring flood hydrographs by removing water on the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="403" speaker="Mr. Finney ">rising side of the hydrograph consistent with the early,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="404" speaker="Mr. Finney ">middle, and late zones.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="405" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2B.10.2 Culvert Inventory: An analysis outlining the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="406" speaker="Mr. Finney ">advantages, disadvantages, benefits, and costs of a basin-wide</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="407" speaker="Mr. Finney ">culvert inventory gathered at the local water board level</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="408" speaker="Mr. Finney ">should be completed by RRBC and presented to the appropriate</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="409" speaker="Mr. Finney ">local and state entities with recommended funding from local,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="410" speaker="Mr. Finney ">state, and Federal sources (2012).</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="411" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2B.10.3 Culvert Size Demonstration Project: A demonstration</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="412" speaker="Mr. Finney ">project in partnership with NRCS and affected local water</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="413" speaker="Mr. Finney ">boards should be implemented to analyze the flow reduction</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="414" speaker="Mr. Finney ">benefits of small distributed and culvert-sizing retention. The</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="415" speaker="Mr. Finney ">project, estimated to cost about $1.5 million, should be 75/25</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="416" speaker="Mr. Finney ">percent Federal/non-Federal cost shared (2012).</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="417" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2B.10.4 Ag Damage Report: The 1980 and 2002 basin</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="418" speaker="Mr. Finney ">agriculture flood damage reports should be updated and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="419" speaker="Mr. Finney ">documented in a continuously updated data base, with Federal</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="420" speaker="Mr. Finney ">funds provided through USDA to provide local project benefit/</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="421" speaker="Mr. Finney ">cost information to assist in local impoundment strategies at</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="422" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the local landowner and water board level.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="423" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2B.10.5 Wetland Water Level Management Pilot Project: Within</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="424" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the next 2 years, a pilot project should be funded by NRCS in</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="425" speaker="Mr. Finney ">cooperation with the RRRA and other appropriate state and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="426" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Federal agencies to draw down wetlands in the autumn enabling</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="427" speaker="Mr. Finney ">spring storage and determining benefits and impacts for habitat</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="428" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and retention.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="429" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2B.10.6 Multi-Purpose Pilot Project: A demonstration project</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="430" speaker="Mr. Finney ">with funding and participation from farm and commodity groups</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="431" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and other interested parties should be developed and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="432" speaker="Mr. Finney ">implemented in 2012, with RRBC assistance, to gather data on</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="433" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the timing and impacts on flooding from the following: tile</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="434" speaker="Mr. Finney ">drainage, surface drainage, wetland restoration, early water</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="435" speaker="Mr. Finney ">ditch drainage, and culvert sizing.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="436" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2B.10.7 Tile Drainage Study: A tile drainage analysis by the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="437" speaker="Mr. Finney ">RRRA through the Basin Technical and Scientific Advisory</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="438" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Committee under the staff direction of the International Water</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="439" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Institute should be funded by the RRWMB and RRJWRD and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="440" speaker="Mr. Finney ">completed in 2012.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="441" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2B.10.8 Buffer Strip: Buffer strips should be established</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="442" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and enforced at the local level for all natural, altered, and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="443" speaker="Mr. Finney ">man-made waterways to a minimum of 16.5 (1 rod) and a maximum</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="444" speaker="Mr. Finney ">of 50 or more with incentives provided to landowners to reduce</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="445" speaker="Mr. Finney ">sediment for water quality and maintenance cost benefits and to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="446" speaker="Mr. Finney ">slow the flow of water into the waterways.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="447" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.11</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="448" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The rural flood control systems that protect agricultural productivity and the economy from spring and summer floods should continue to be implemented throughout the basin. The goal is to reduce crop loss and to reduce planting delays by moving water off of land by mid-May in the spring and maximize flood control designs for peak run off for a 24 hour summer rainfall event with a 10 year reoccurrence interval.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="449" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Critical Transportation System and Emergency Services: <bullet> The Red River basin covers approximately 45,000\2\ miles or</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="450" speaker="Mr. Finney ">28 million acres, a majority directly in active agricultural</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="451" speaker="Mr. Finney ">production, with an extensive system of highways, roads, and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="452" speaker="Mr. Finney ">bridges that provide for the movement of goods and people to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="453" speaker="Mr. Finney ">enhance the economic output of the region. <bullet> The RRBC should facilitate discussions with regional</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="454" speaker="Mr. Finney ">organizations, state and Federal departments of transportation,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="455" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and EMOs, to identify a strategy for critical transportation</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="456" speaker="Mr. Finney ">preservation including potential road elevations during 100,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="457" speaker="Mr. Finney ">200, and 500 year flood levels compatible with the LTFS level</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="458" speaker="Mr. Finney ">of protection goals. <bullet> Critical transportation and emergency services throughout</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="459" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the basin are inconsistent with each other and fail to operate</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="460" speaker="Mr. Finney ">effectively for a typical flood event.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="461" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.12</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="462" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Minnesota and North Dakota should each explore the issues surrounding dedicating a portion of state aid for highway funding for culvert sizing and related road modifications that benefit basin flood damage reduction strategies and introduce legislation to change state law if necessary. The RRBC shall assist with facilitation the discussion and analysis, by the end of 2013.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="463" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.13</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="464" speaker="Mr. Finney ">An analysis of planned and proposed road elevations for 100, 200, and 500 year flood protection at township, county and state levels for emergency, population sustainability, and agricultural and economic production needs shall be developed. Engineering expertise funded and directed by the RRWMB, RRJWRD, and appropriate state agencies should identify needs by location and hydrologic impacts on flooding by change of flows, elevation of the flood stage, and other related impacts using the new LiDAR data.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="465" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.14</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="466" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Minnesota and North Dakota should develop through their Departments of Transportation, a state and local funding strategy to assist in county and township flood-related road repairs and implement additional flood mitigation efforts once the protection goals are achieved and Federal emergency aid under a disaster declaration is less likely.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="467" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2B.15</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="468" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The RRBC should facilitate discussions with relevant regional organizations, state and Federal departments of transportation, and emergency management offices to identify a strategy for critical transportation preservation, including potential road elevations during the 100, 200, and 500 year flood levels, and to identify state and Federal funding needs.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="469" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2C Floodplain Management--Retention <bullet> No comprehensive, basin-wide strategy exists to implement</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="470" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the LTFS minimum 20 percent flow reduction goal for the main</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="471" speaker="Mr. Finney ">stem while achieving local tributary flood damage reduction. <bullet> The impacts of retention are often dependant on timing and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="472" speaker="Mr. Finney ">location. Not all sites are equally beneficial for local</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="473" speaker="Mr. Finney ">tributary and basin main stem flood damage reduction. <bullet> Flow reduction through retention as demonstrated by modeling</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="474" speaker="Mr. Finney ">can reduce flows and stages on the Red River main stem as well</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="475" speaker="Mr. Finney ">as provide local benefits on tributaries. However, due to the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="476" speaker="Mr. Finney ">variability of flood events, retention must be used in</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="477" speaker="Mr. Finney ">conjunction with other structural and non-structural measures</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="478" speaker="Mr. Finney ">to achieve the LTFS goals that will result in basin-wide</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="479" speaker="Mr. Finney ">improved levels of protection. <bullet> The minimum goal for flow reduction on the Red River main</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="480" speaker="Mr. Finney ">stem at the international boundary for a 100 year flood equates</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="481" speaker="Mr. Finney ">to around 1.5 million acre-feet of storage upstream accounting</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="482" speaker="Mr. Finney ">for timing of flow and costing approximately $1.5 billion. <bullet> Retention using the minimum 20 percent flow reduction goal</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="483" speaker="Mr. Finney ">basin-wide can be achieved over the next 20 years if local,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="484" speaker="Mr. Finney ">state, and Federal funds are leveraged to provide comprehensive</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="485" speaker="Mr. Finney ">local, tributary and main stem benefits for residents,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="486" speaker="Mr. Finney ">property, and the environment. <bullet> Retention that will cumulatively achieve the basin minimum</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="487" speaker="Mr. Finney ">20 percent flow reductions over the next 20 to 25 years should</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="488" speaker="Mr. Finney ">be managed to improve flood control, improve water quality,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="489" speaker="Mr. Finney ">include natural resource enhancement opportunities, and provide</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="490" speaker="Mr. Finney ">potential water supply during extended droughts. <bullet> Numerous small, aged P.L. 83-566 flood control dams</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="491" speaker="Mr. Finney ">throughout the basin could provide additional capacity for</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="492" speaker="Mr. Finney ">flood storage retention with refurbishment.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="493" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.1</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="494" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Federal funding should be provided for retention at $25 million per year or $500 million over the next 20 years, with Minnesota, North Dakota, and local governments providing cost share funding for retention to achieve a minimum 20 percent reduction in peak flows on the Red River.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="495" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.2</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="496" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Cost for retention projects should be shared among Federal (50 to 75 percent), states of Minnesota and North Dakota (25 to 35 percent), and the RRWMB, RRJWRD and local water boards (10 to 25 percent) over a period of 20 years staying within the current local joint board two mil levy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="497" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.3</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="498" speaker="Mr. Finney ">A review of federally operated reservoirs, identifying the potential for increased storage during flood events, should be conducted by USACE and state agencies, and Wildlife Management Areas by the USFWS, reporting to relevant state agencies and the RRRA.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="499" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.4</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="500" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The newly formed RRRA should work with each water management board to plan, design, and implement retention, to achieve 25 percent of the retention goal every 5 years for their respective areas, with the goal of achieving the minimum 20 percent flow reduction for the Red River main stem over 20-25 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="501" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.5</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="502" speaker="Mr. Finney ">A project prioritization methodology for the use of Federal funds reflecting local and main stem needs and benefits should be developed by the RRRA by 2012.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="503" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.6</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="504" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The permitting process for water retention projects should be coordinated by the RRRA and a Federal agency liaison in the basin working with appropriate state and Federal agencies to help streamline the process to decrease timelines for project implementation, allow a one-stop permitting process, and provide general permits for certain projects.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="505" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.7</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="506" speaker="Mr. Finney ">NRCS and/or the states of Minnesota and North Dakota should provide $400,000 to expand the Project Planning and Permit Evaluation demonstration project to the entire Red River basin through the International Water Institute as part of the USACE Basin Watershed Feasibility Study.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="507" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.8</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="508" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Public outreach on retention programs and a survey to determine landowner interest in storing water on their land should be completed in 2 years by the RRWMB and RRJWRD (or the RRRA) to assist in future planning for retention projects and determine achievable timelines and cost expectations that correspond to local participation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="509" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.9</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="510" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Regarding the ongoing USACE Red River Basin-wide Feasibility Study:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="511" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2C.9.1 The current ongoing study shall be continued with</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="512" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Federal funding at $1 million per year and corresponding $1</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="513" speaker="Mr. Finney ">million non-Federal match.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="514" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2C.9.2 The updating of HMS (hydrologic modeling system) of</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="515" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the remaining major watersheds should be completed by the end</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="516" speaker="Mr. Finney ">of 2012. This modeling will provide the tools necessary to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="517" speaker="Mr. Finney ">identify retention projects on tributaries that provide local</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="518" speaker="Mr. Finney ">benefits and cumulatively benefit the basin.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="519" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2C.9.3 Modeling of the remaining main stem Hydrologic</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="520" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Engineering Centers River Analysis System HEC-RAS reach to the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="521" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Canadian border presently underway, including the work needed</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="522" speaker="Mr. Finney ">to tie all the main stem reaches together into one model from</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="523" speaker="Mr. Finney ">White Rock, South Dakota, to the Canadian border, should be</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="524" speaker="Mr. Finney ">completed by the end of 2012.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="525" speaker="Mr. Finney ">2C.9.4 The HEC-RAS main stem model, in conjunction with the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="526" speaker="Mr. Finney ">new watershed HMS models, should be finalized in such a way</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="527" speaker="Mr. Finney ">that they can be utilized to provide the basis for a RRRA</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="528" speaker="Mr. Finney ">``Project Prioritization Process'' needed for evaluating</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="529" speaker="Mr. Finney ">proposed projects, their effectiveness, and downstream impacts</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="530" speaker="Mr. Finney ">in contributing to the RRBC's flow reduction goals on the major</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="531" speaker="Mr. Finney ">tributaries and Red River main stem.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="532" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 2C.10</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="533" speaker="Mr. Finney ">NRCS, in conjunction the RRRA, shall evaluate P.L. 83-566 and other dams that have flood control capacity in the basin to determine the feasibility of restoration for the purpose of adding potential flood water retention storage, including the identification of specific structures for rehabilitation, specific strategies and funding necessary, and proposed timelines. NRCS shall issue its findings to the RRRA by September 30, 2012. Federal funding of up to $6 million is needed for the evaluation and an additional estimated $10-$15 million for refurbishment. 3. Information and Tools for Maximizing Efforts Going Forward <bullet> The Red River Basin, a vast geographic area of three states</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="534" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and one Canadian province, has great need for cooperation</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="535" speaker="Mr. Finney ">across boundaries for uniform data and information gathering</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="536" speaker="Mr. Finney ">efforts, an understanding of our differences, and a shared</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="537" speaker="Mr. Finney ">vision of what needs to be accomplished. <bullet> The current local, state, and Federal partnership in</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="538" speaker="Mr. Finney ">comprehensive flood risk reduction strategies is disjointed and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="539" speaker="Mr. Finney ">operates in a piecemeal fashion. <bullet> Each flood varies, creating unique issues regarding</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="540" speaker="Mr. Finney ">preparation and protection needs. <bullet> Levels of protection recommended by RRBC for the LTFS Report</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="541" speaker="Mr. Finney ">will provide the safety net needed and allow for variations in</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="542" speaker="Mr. Finney ">floods, weather, and forecasting. <bullet> Further improvements in flood forecasting such as new data</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="543" speaker="Mr. Finney ">sets, modeling improvements, and real time information to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="544" speaker="Mr. Finney ">account for variables related to precipitation and temperature</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="545" speaker="Mr. Finney ">are needed to build upon those instituted after the 1997 flood. <bullet> Additional efforts and information are needed as a guide for</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="546" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the future as updated needs become evident.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="547" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 3.1</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="548" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The RRBC shall, for the next 10 years, conduct an annual evaluation of flood mitigation progress towards the implementation of the LTFS Report Recommendations. This evaluation shall be submitted to Minnesota, North Dakota, South Dakota, and Manitoba.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="549" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 3.2</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="550" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Jurisdictional Multi-Boundary Coordination should be implemented wherever possible through the RRBC.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="551" speaker="Mr. Finney ">3.2.1 The Minnesota, North Dakota, and South Dakota</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="552" speaker="Mr. Finney ">governors and the Manitoba Premier should meet at least once</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="553" speaker="Mr. Finney ">every 2 years, along with the relevant legislative committee</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="554" speaker="Mr. Finney ">chairs of the state and provincial governments, to receive an</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="555" speaker="Mr. Finney ">update on progress towards the LTFS recommendations on flood</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="556" speaker="Mr. Finney ">reduction strategies, water quality, water quantity, and other</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="557" speaker="Mr. Finney ">relevant natural resource issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="558" speaker="Mr. Finney ">3.2.2 With the assistance of RRBC, the International</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="559" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Legislators Forum among Manitoba, Minnesota, North Dakota, and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="560" speaker="Mr. Finney ">South Dakota legislators should be continued to discuss current</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="561" speaker="Mr. Finney ">topics, including flood risk reduction strategies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="562" speaker="Mr. Finney ">3.2.3 Minnesota should coordinate through the Board of Water</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="563" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and Soil Resources and the state legislature the inclusion of</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="564" speaker="Mr. Finney ">all subwatersheds on the Minnesota side as Watershed Watershed District).</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="567" speaker="Mr. Finney ">3.2.4 Federal agencies should utilize their regional</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="568" speaker="Mr. Finney ">structures in innovative new ways to accommodate Red River</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="569" speaker="Mr. Finney ">basin hydrologic boundaries.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="570" speaker="Mr. Finney ">3.2.5 When necessary, RRBC shall coordinate a jurisdictional</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="571" speaker="Mr. Finney ">meeting of heads of state, legislative leaders, and key agency</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="572" speaker="Mr. Finney ">officials to prompt dialogue and development of unified action</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="573" speaker="Mr. Finney ">on such issues.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="574" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 3.3</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="575" speaker="Mr. Finney ">LTFS should be expanded to include the entire Red River basin:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="576" speaker="Mr. Finney ">3.3.1 Manitoba should continue funding RRBC's efforts to</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="577" speaker="Mr. Finney ">model the 20 percent flow reduction strategy in Manitoba and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="578" speaker="Mr. Finney ">also continue and accelerate the gathering of Light Detection</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="579" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and Ranging (LiDAR) data, at $70,000 through 2012.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="580" speaker="Mr. Finney ">3.3.2 South Dakota and local leadership should determine the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="581" speaker="Mr. Finney ">feasibility of establishing watershed organizations in Roberts</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="582" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and Marshall counties through the International Legislators</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="583" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Forum within the next 2 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="584" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 3.4</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="585" speaker="Mr. Finney ">RRBC should coordinate development of a basin-wide strategy and identification of funding sources for improving flood forecasting during 2012 among local, state, provincial, and Federal agencies.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="586" speaker="Mr. Finney ">3.4.1 The generation of relevant time appropriate data (real</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="587" speaker="Mr. Finney ">time rain and snowmelt, soil moisture, frost depth information,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="588" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and other information) and improved modeling through a</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="589" speaker="Mr. Finney ">volunteer network and the development of a real time network</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="590" speaker="Mr. Finney ">shall be addressed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="591" speaker="Mr. Finney ">3.4.2 The feasibility of establishing an on-site decision</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="592" speaker="Mr. Finney ">support service to the region during spring and summer flood</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="593" speaker="Mr. Finney ">events by hosting a U.S. National Weather Service hydrologist</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="594" speaker="Mr. Finney ">in the basin shall be considered, as well as identifying a</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="595" speaker="Mr. Finney ">funding source for such an effort.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="596" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 3.5</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="597" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The USGS, RRWMB, RRJWRD, and their member water boards, NDSWC, MNDNR, and other key stakeholders, should develop a stream gage strategy by 2012 with associated costs and funders for the basin for the main stem Red River and its tributaries that will support the new hydrologic and hydraulic models that will provide a long term record for accurate, timely, and consistent flow data for model development, aid in flood reduction strategies, and include water quality modeling needs in the next 2 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="598" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendation for Action 3.6</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="599" speaker="Mr. Finney ">RRBC should update the LTFS Report in 2021 with the inclusion of Manitoba and South Dakota and shared funding from the four jurisdictions. 4. Resources to Implement <bullet> Minnesota and North Dakota, cost-sharing with local, state,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="600" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and Federal funds, should implement actions consistent with the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="601" speaker="Mr. Finney ">LTFS to maintain the basin's social, economic, and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="602" speaker="Mr. Finney ">environmental welfare and protection from future large floods,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="603" speaker="Mr. Finney ">as this investment over the next 10 years will significantly</paragraph> <paragraph basin.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="606" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Recommendations for Action 4.1</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="607" speaker="Mr. Finney ">The States of Minnesota and North Dakota, paraId="685" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Sub-committee observations:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="686" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Tile has potential to be used as a water management tool in the Red River Basin. Experts from North Dakota State University, the Energy and Environmental Research Center, the tiling industry, International Water Institute and private landowners have conducted or are working on short-term studies on this type of water management. The preliminary findings show a need for further evaluation and study.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="687" speaker="Mr. Finney ">There appears to be the potential to gain efficiencies in water retention, protect public safety, improve soil health and water quality. There are some studies indicating the soil can hold more water in the spring, but these studies are not conclusive. Many of the reports on water management efficiencies are anecdotal and need to be further studied by the scientific community. The potential is real, but we need to be certain we are not solving one water resource issue while creating another. Retention Committee Permitting Sub-committee Chad L. Engels, Chairman</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="688" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Sub-Committee Recommendations: <bullet> EPA Guideline Change[:]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="689" speaker="Mr. Finney "><ctr-circle> EPA 404(b)(1) Guidelines, set out in 40 CFR section</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="690" speaker="Mr. Finney ">230 (LEDPA)--404(b)(1) states a permit will not be issued</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="691" speaker="Mr. Finney ">``if there is a practicable alternative to the proposed</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="692" speaker="Mr. Finney ">discharge which would have less adverse impact on the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="693" speaker="Mr. Finney ">aquatic ecosystem, so long as the alternative does not have</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="694" speaker="Mr. Finney ">other significant adverse environmental consequences.'' Our</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="695" speaker="Mr. Finney ">subcommittee has identified LEDPA as a significant obstacle</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="696" speaker="Mr. Finney ">to building retention projects in terms of time and money.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="697" speaker="Mr. Finney ">A solution would be to replace The Least Environmental</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="698" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Damaging Practicable Alternative (LEDPA) requirement with a</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="699" speaker="Mr. Finney ">simple environmental mitigation requirement for the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="700" speaker="Mr. Finney ">proposed project. <bullet> SAMP[:]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="701" speaker="Mr. Finney "><ctr-circle> EPA 404 Nationwide Permit/Regional Permit--Currently,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="702" speaker="Mr. Finney ">retention projects must be permitted as individual</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="703" speaker="Mr. Finney ">projects. Our subcommittee has learned that many categories</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="704" speaker="Mr. Finney ">of projects are permitted under what are called</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="705" speaker="Mr. Finney ">``Nationwide Permits'' or ``Regional permits''. These</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="706" speaker="Mr. Finney ">permit categories speed the process significantly by having</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="707" speaker="Mr. Finney ">a common ``Purpose and Need'' and ``Description of Proposed</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="708" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Alternatives and No Action Alternative'' in the EIS</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="709" speaker="Mr. Finney ">requirements for flood retention projects covered by this</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="710" speaker="Mr. Finney ">national or regional permit. Therefore, our subcommittee</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="711" speaker="Mr. Finney ">will likely recommend that a Nationwide Permit (preferable)</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="712" speaker="Mr. Finney ">or Regional General Permit (second choice) be developed for</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="713" speaker="Mr. Finney ">three categories of retention projects in the Red River of</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="714" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the North Watershed. These project categories include Off-</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="715" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Channel projects like North Ottawa, dry mainstem projects</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="716" speaker="Mr. Finney ">like the Maple River Dam, and wetland retention projects</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="717" speaker="Mr. Finney ">that temporarily store water above the delineated wetland</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="718" speaker="Mr. Finney ">boundary.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="719" speaker="Mr. Finney "><ctr-circle> Consistency--The USACE should establish an interagency</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="720" speaker="Mr. Finney ">agreement whereby one office assumes regulatory control of</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="721" speaker="Mr. Finney ">retention projects within the entire Red River of the North</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="722" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Watershed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="723" speaker="Mr. Finney "><ctr-circle> Funding--The Federal Government should fund a USACE</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="724" speaker="Mr. Finney ">regulatory position dedicated solely to processing Federal</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="725" speaker="Mr. Finney ">permits for retention projects in the Red River of the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="726" speaker="Mr. Finney ">North Watershed.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="727" speaker="Mr. Finney "><ctr-circle> Involvement--The USACE should be a committed, active,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="728" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and involved participant in the ``Flood Damage Reduction</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="729" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Work Group--Watershed District Project Teams'' process for</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="730" speaker="Mr. Finney ">developing retention projects in Minnesota. Additionally,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="731" speaker="Mr. Finney ">the USACE should be involved at the ground level, if</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="732" speaker="Mr. Finney ">requested, for retention projects developed in North Dakota</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="733" speaker="Mr. Finney ">and South Dakota. <bullet> Corps Rule 40 CFR Change[:]</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="734" speaker="Mr. Finney "><ctr-circle> NEPA Council on Environmental Quality (CEQ) Comment</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="735" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Period--would recommend that Corps rules be changed so that</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="736" speaker="Mr. Finney ">under no circumstances can the three comment periods</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="737" speaker="Mr. Finney ">required under an EIS be extended beyond 30 days for the</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="738" speaker="Mr. Finney ">Notice of Intent, 45 days for the Draft EIS, and 30 days</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="739" speaker="Mr. Finney ">for the Final EIS. But it is still very important that we manage that land above them and below them so that we can slow that water. Ranking Member Fudge talked about the water quality downstream that will be greatly enhanced if we can do that. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Kelly</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1020" speaker="Mr. Kelly">And I would just say that the watershed programs do so much for the local communities, many of the people who don't even realize the value that it gets for them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1021" speaker="Mr. Kelly">I thank all you gentlemen for what you have done in this program.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1022" speaker="Mr. Kelly"> And, Mr. Chairman, I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>The Chairman. The gentleman yields back"> The chair recognizes the gentleman from California for 5 minutes. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LaMalfa</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1025" speaker="Mr. LaMalfa">Thank you again, Mr. Chairman, and for the panelists for traveling here today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1026" speaker="Mr. LaMalfa">Mr. Peterson, on the issue, I hear it from farmers and ranchers back home, with NRCS. That was mentioned early on in your testimony.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1027" speaker="Mr. LaMalfa"> Aside from budgets, what structural change do you think would be helpful to NRCS' program to stock it with the right people who can do more--well, I won't prejudice the question. Now they are down around 10,500 people with far more program responsibilities than they used to have. And here we are trying to implement a lot of these programs that require competent professional staff. The agency, from the time I left it 25 years ago until today, has lost a great deal of the people that we need to manage these programs properly, and I would just like to see that stopped. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LaMalfa</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1029" speaker="Mr. LaMalfa"> Okay, so no more cuts. We ran out of minutes on that, as it goes up here.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1032" speaker="Mr. LaMalfa"> Anybody else on the panel wish to touch on that. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Peterson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1033" speaker="Mr. Peterson"> I can touch on one fact, that the permitting process is quite lengthy, even though there is a section 404 process, and there are some practices that are put on the ground that require mitigation. And these projects should be receiving the credits for the mitigation rather than having to give them, if that makes sense, because it is---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LaMalfa</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1036" speaker="Mr. LaMalfa"> Do you feel it is outside of the law where there are clear exemptions for a lot of agriculture, other activities that were pretty clear as Congress wrote them, and then they have been overtaken by interpretations that are---- </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Peterson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1037" speaker="Mr. Peterson"> I believe you are correct. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. LaMalfa</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1038" speaker="Mr. LaMalfa"> What do you think we should be doing about that? </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Peterson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1039" speaker="Mr. Peterson"> Streamline it in some way. We have been able to implement these kinds of practices to avoid soil erosion as well wind erosion and also protect the waters coming down from upstream to downstream into our retention projects. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Thompson</speaker> <paragraph paraId="1072" speaker="Mr. Thompson">Very good.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="1073" speaker="Mr. Thompson"> Thank you, Mr. Chairman.
